issue.title: Datetime in result elements of sources to targets are in UTC not local as documentation states

comment.body:
It's true that it'd be only consequent to allow it on the input. But since we know which timezones are where, we correlate that ourselves. For us, the initial timezone doesn't really matter that much even, we're mostly interested in timezone changes. And then a client would still input the exact same local time but with a `+02:00` (for Berlin) appended, more or less ISO 8601 conform. In other words, in any case the client will have to know about the local time. The alternative of accepting UTC and a timezone could be done as well, but that'd be a bigger change and a bit functionally redundant, as it's still trivial to convert to local time.

But for destinations, the client never knows which timezone we landed in. And that's not so trivial to find out client-side. Plus Valhalla knows about it already, so IMO returning with timezone is more crucial.

repo.description: Open Source Routing Engine for OpenStreetMap

issue.title: Datetime in result elements of sources to targets are in UTC not local as documentation states

comment.body:
> Hmpf, that's my bad.. thanks for reporting. Personally, instead of just fixing this, I'd like to see #4241 done. Local time is good, but timezone-aware is better IMO and we have all the info to return it. Any opinions on this?

It would be better to have timezone here. I agree. For us would be greatly beneficial if we could specify the departure datetime, including its timezone, or use the 'Z' (zulu) parameter on the input. This is because we store all our data in UTC, and converting them to local time is redundant for us. While I understand that many high-level applications, such as routing websites, may require local time, when Valhalla is used as a low-level routing service, it would make sense to allow setting time awareness in UTC—whether by specifying the zone as +00:00 or supporting the ISO 'Z' format."

we have to respect `motorcar` as well though. I'm not sure what would be the best thing here, as that usually implies in some way that motorcycle & motorscooter are affected as well. If it's a `kTimedDenied` it usually doesn't count for motorcycles and they're still allowed, but if it's a `kTimedAllowed` it should also allow motorcycles. so maybe it `motorcar` needs to distinguish the type? That's what https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:motorcar suggests.

issue.title: Ferry Reclassification - Can reclassify nearly all edges on small islands

comment.body: Hm, just seeing that we don't even try to reclassify if the connection edge is a primary.. I wonder what Tsawwassen looked like before.. Still, the thought is still similar: if we expand on more than 20-30 consecutive primary (or higher) edges on the same expansion branch, we assume it's fine, break and reclassify?

issue.title: Ferry Reclassification - Can reclassify nearly all edges on small islands

comment.body:
The main reason why the referenced condition in there like that, seems to be that some ferry connections are high class but only connect to low classes further inland, right? (FWIW, the [Tsawwassen terminal](https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=17/49.00772/-123.12958) is only trunk roads these days) 

Couldn't we do smth like we do for `dest_only` edges connecting to ferries: expand from the connection edge and if it's a primary or higher don't let the `GetBestNonFerryClass` condition kick in as long as we didn't expand onto a lower class first? If there's stuff that does this

```
----------x--------------x-----------------x----------------x--------------------x
ferry       primary        service        primary           service
```
that wouldn't hold of course, but honestly, that seems pretty messed up. 

We'd need to protect against ferry terminals like Tsawwassen where the ferry directly connects to the full trunk network, e.g. if we saw more than 20-30 primary edges in a row, we'd break and assume we don't need to upclass. It's not accurate either in all situations but I think it might lead to less problems.

Then we wouldn't have to care about any random limit of found primaries or even number of iterations. Any limit would (and currently does) very likely also cause non-shortest paths to be upclassed if the 33rd primary road is randomly somewhere pretty far away (though a distance instead of node limit would alleviate some of that). And if there's no primary to be found, the adj list is run empty and we don't upclass anything (I agree, that's a gross oversight that we still do upclass currently).

issue.title: Ferry Approach Edge Reclassification - Recovers multiple edges from node on ShortestPath
issue.body:
I added a log statement in graphbuilder to identify driveways that are reclassified by the ferry_connections logic in mjolnir. I found that the ShortestPath method stores the node and its predecessor (and cost) along the ShortestPath from the ferry connection node. This can lead to multiple edges being reclassified when there are multiple edge between two nodes as in the case below:

![image](https://github.com/valhalla/valhalla/assets/1838768/79b5559b-73ac-41a2-b869-aeb5dccc5732)

This is on Long Island, NY - this driveway (https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/1003285180) ends up being reclassified. 

To fix this, we can add the edge wayindex to the node labels for the shortest path. Then when recovering the edges along the ShortestPath (edges to be reclassified) we can check for matching edge wayindex so we don't pick the higher cost path between 2 edges.

One point of discussion - ferry entrances with multiple "lanes" could benefit from this "bug" as it would reclassify more edges in these cases. However, in a route it would still construct shortest paths using only one lane so it likely doesn't matter if only one is reclassified and allows use in longer routes where road class hierarchy comes into play.

![image](https://github.com/valhalla/valhalla/assets/1838768/b6008453-a565-4f54-8f68-4fe76bf26bca)

comment.body:
> To fix this, we can add the edge wayindex to the node labels for the shortest path

makes sense to me

issue.title: Ferry Reclassification - Can reclassify nearly all edges on small islands
Ferry Reclassification - Can reclassify nearly all edges on small islands

comment.body:
if we dont reclassify them the island becomes a "destination (or origin) only" island right? this would essentially make rural ferry ports unusable on longer routes, which might be ok but it would be interesting to see on how many ferries the reclassify algorithm would give up. we need to log these so we can at least quanitfy the problem and maybe hone in on a magical value that works for most ports. maybe its 32, maybe its 42, maybe 111?

also maybe it might be better to base it on distance rather than on number of nodes. after we fix the other issue were we only upclass the shortest path, if we find that the expansion has made it 10 miles (or whatever number) away from the ferry or something maybe its best not to upclass anything there.

Ferry Approach Edge Reclassification - Recovers multiple edges from node on ShortestPath
issue.body:
I added a log statement in graphbuilder to identify driveways that are reclassified by the ferry_connections logic in mjolnir. I found that the ShortestPath method stores the node and its predecessor (and cost) along the ShortestPath from the ferry connection node. This can lead to multiple edges being reclassified when there are multiple edge between two nodes as in the case below:

![image](https://github.com/valhalla/valhalla/assets/1838768/79b5559b-73ac-41a2-b869-aeb5dccc5732)

This is on Long Island, NY - this driveway (https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/1003285180) ends up being reclassified. 

To fix this, we can add the edge wayindex to the node labels for the shortest path. Then when recovering the edges along the ShortestPath (edges to be reclassified) we can check for matching edge wayindex so we don't pick the higher cost path between 2 edges.

issue.title: add --optimize & --log-details to valhalla_run_matrix
issue.body: the logging it does clutters the terminal enormously and often I'm not interested in its output. and I made optimization optional per arg.

comment.body: BTW, I can also negate the flags to preserve current behavior (i.e. `--no-optimize` etc), in case you rely on it.

issue.title: Static cast from unsigned int64 to int could be problematic
Cast from UInt64 to Int could be problematic on macOS
issue.body:
https://github.com/valhalla/valhalla/blob/5b3cd9704ffd699b992b08bc4a5bf60e34d318f5/src/tyr/serializers.cc#L442

num_lanes_blocked is defined as UInt64, writer writes Int. This gives an compiler error on default build configuration.

comment.body: it likely depends on your platform and compiler, as you can see our builds complete without issue. in practice, its highly unlikely that this matters. no roads that i know about have more than 2^31 lanes, so the number wouldnt wrap around on the signed integer conversion. that said, you are right that we should fix it. it looks like there are a number of places where we just use `Int` without looking at the sign :frowning_face: do you have time to submit a pr?
